name: NPR
text:
Four federal judges have been killed since 1979, and the number of threats is skyrocketing, according to the U.S. Marshals Service — which reported nearly 4,500 threats and "inappropriate communications" last year.
https://t.co/9L5zsOfKSO

name: NPR
text:
Ben Carson says he was "desperately ill" with the coronavirus but is now "out of the woods," crediting his recovery to monoclonal antibody treatments. 

He said he hopes "we can stop playing politics with medicine."
https://t.co/m3r1wUw5Nt

name: NPR
text:
NPR asked Americans how they think the nation can move forward.

And people shared their thoughts — from bolstering voting infrastructure and abolishing the Electoral College to addressing the problem of misinformation and regulating social media.
https://t.co/AZgDcHWiiw

name: NPR
text:
Since Trump appointee Michael Pack took charge of USAGM, he's erased protections for government journalists and rejected visas for foreign staffers. There have been firings and lawsuits.

Now, staffers say they fear more damage from Pack on his way out.
https://t.co/jy5Mh4mHCt

name: NPR
text:
A Black man was killed in an attack by 2 security guards in southern Brazil on Thursday, causing outrage on the eve of the nation's observance of Black Consciousness Day.

A day later, Vice President Mourão proclaimed "racism doesn't exist in Brazil."
https://t.co/rA5yAMGDe5

name: NPR
text:
More than 1,000 hospitals across the U.S. are "critically" short on staff, according to HHS data. The worst-hit state is North Dakota with 51% of hospitals reporting shortages.
https://t.co/2B4BkuXF2o

name: NPR
text:
Judge Merrick Garland is under consideration to serve as attorney general in the Biden administration, NPR has learned from two people closely following the process.
https://t.co/cFllFvUbvp

name: NPR
text:
Donald Trump is already the subject of investigations by New York officials — and there's a chance federal authorities may implicate him.

One thing is certain: As a private citizen, he'll no longer enjoy de facto immunity. 
https://t.co/wofaIRWW75

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Joe Biden is assembling his inner circle of advisers and Cabinet officials.

Here's who has been named and nominated so far.
https://t.co/EzMpWOGtae

name: NPR
text:
It's much riskier to exercise indoors. In Hamilton, Ontario, over 60 coronavirus cases were linked to one spin studio last month.

Here's what experts say about indoor activities ⤵️
https://t.co/Nwr3hvN7jH

name: NPR
text: As of Friday, more than three-fourths of the inmates at Iowa's state prison had tested positive for coronavirus. Other facilities in the state have infection rates as high as 90%. @IowaPublicRadio https://t.co/gjoxZKXyCR

name: NPR
text:
In 2017, after Judge James Robart blocked Trump's ban on travel from mainly Muslim countries, the president tweeted derogatory comments, calling Robart a "so-called judge."

Robart received over 100 death threats, according to the American Bar Association.
https://t.co/1yPAOahbRp

name: NPR
text:
Vermont's Republican governor has embraced COVID-19 safety measures. South Dakota's Republican governor has loudly opposed them.

Their infection rates:
◾  Vermont — about 500 cases per 100,000 people
◾ South Dakota — about 8,000 cases per 100,000 people
https://t.co/QNDZcVMOF5

name: NPR
text: Thanksgiving's going to be a bit smaller for many families this year, but it's still a great opportunity to start great conversations and learn more about your loved ones. Learn more about the @StoryCorps Great Thanksgiving Listen: https://t.co/5Nt95iNs0S

name: NPR
text: Massachusetts foster parents had discussed unionizing for more than a year, but the pandemic added urgency. Foster parenting now includes getting PPE, homeschooling, and ensuring that visits with social workers and biological parents are safe. @hereandnow https://t.co/ZjqgLWkTT8

name: NPR
text:
Rachael is the mother of five, living in her father-in-law's two bedroom apartment. 

Listen to her story here: https://t.co/h1dV7dHzPE

name: NPR
text:
New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo will receive the International Emmy Founders Award for his daily coronavirus briefings — which "worked so well because he effectively created television shows, with characters, plot lines, and stories of success and failure."
https://t.co/EqPzDeljcD

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has ordered the CEO over the Voice of America to stop investigating its journalists for anti-Trump bias, saying his actions led to “self-censorship and the chilling of First Amendment expression.”
https://t.co/57gPafQ2Ld

name: NPR
text: Most presidents spend their final weeks in office trying to cement their legacies. But Trump's tactics since he lost to Biden have raised alarms that he's doing damage to confidence in free and fair elections. https://t.co/FwDAcsnElD

name: NPR
text:
At least 8 people are dead and 31 more injured after nearly two dozen rockets rained down on Kabul on a day that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo had earmarked for discussing peace efforts in Afghanistan.
https://t.co/B4xy0WEKxq

name: NPR
text:
A first-of-its-kind climate action program, Portland's Clean Energy Fund is reserved for things like clean energy job training and adding rooftop solar panels in communities most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change.
https://t.co/X7tqjoSrQT

name: NPR
text:
The Portland Clean Energy Fund will help address "centuries of underinvestment" in communities of color and those with low income, according to the program manager.

"We see this as an economic recovery tool," an advocate says. https://t.co/u1w1xH1bYZ

name: NPR
text:
Hari Kondabolu and W. Kamau Bell, comedians and co-hosts of the podcast "Politically Re-Active," discuss how the left is processing the results of the 2020 election on this episode of @NPRItsBeenaMin. 

Listen to their full conversation with @samsanders: https://t.co/Vh2PuWEz0P https://t.co/Ss6o8XUAXI

name: NPR
text:
Judge Merrick Garland is under consideration to serve as attorney general in the Biden administration, NPR has learned from two people closely following the process.
https://t.co/Rq1icKTqzf

name: NPR
text: As Trump and Pence refuse to concede their loss, the GOP is left with a tricky argument: claiming Georgia's two Senate seats are their last line of defense against Democrats — which they wouldn't need if Trump and Pence had won. https://t.co/WLmjGZTUpk

name: NPR
text: RT @EmilyZFeng: NEW: last year I reported from NW/central China on material restrictions on religion: mosque domes removed, imams banished. Now China is targeting the intellectual and spiritual soul of Islam across China, a pattern familiar to those in Xinjiang https://t.co/hFFyuuZp8h

name: NPR
text: An arrangement to allow air travelers between Hong Kong and Singapore to bypass a 14-day quarantine has been delayed after Hong Kong reported a spike in coronavirus cases. https://t.co/461S3owBJr

name: NPR
text:
For years, historian and travel writer Jan Morris was best-known for her 1974 memoir about her gender transition in her 40s, which she wrote was "like a lost traveler finding the right road at last."

@nprscottsimon remembers Morris, who died Friday at 94. https://t.co/cDBkj8bXFp
